metadata.title: Why One Should – or Should Not – Wait Before Bringing Children Into the World
metadata.summary: Deciding when to have children is a deeply personal choice with no definitive answer. This article explores both sides of the debate—waiting until you're 'ready' versus embracing parenthood despite uncertainty. It discusses key factors like emotional stability, financial security, and relationship readiness, while also acknowledging that no one is ever truly prepared. Parenthood can be a catalyst for growth, forcing individuals to mature and take responsibility. However, bringing a child into an unstable situation can have lasting consequences. The piece concludes with a balanced perspective: while waiting too long can mean missing out on life’s most rewarding experience, jumping in without any preparation can lead to struggle. Ultimately, the best indicator of readiness is not perfection but the willingness to step up and embrace the challenges of raising a child. If you have the basics in place and the commitment to grow, you might already be more ready than you think.
metadata.author: Björn van der Lugt

sections.heading: Why One Should – or Should Not – Wait Before Bringing Children Into the World

images.alt: A Romantic-era painting showing ships at sea, symbolizing different stages of life and time passing.
images.caption: Caspar David Friedrich’s 1835 *The Stages of Life* reflects on human mortality and time’s passage, using distant ships as metaphors for different phases of existence.

paragraphs.content: When are we ready to bring children into the world? This is one of those dilemmas that unfortunately can't be answered definitively. Instead, we are left with two perspectives, and deciding which one is best is only a guess—your guess is as good as mine. I'd like to explore both viewpoints, play advocate on both sides, and finish with my two cents on the matter. But before I do so…

This article is written from the viewpoint of a 30 year western man living in the Netherlands. That said, I think if we reflect on it, we'd all reach roughly the same conclusion, no matter where we come from or who we are. Readiness might look something like this:

items: One is of a certain age (though the exact age varies greatly depending on culture and background).

One has dealt with personal baggage (childhood trauma, unresolved psychological issues, etc.). While no one is ever completely free of their past, certain deep-seated issues—such as severe emotional instability, destructive habits, or an inability to handle stress—can significantly impact parenting. Some struggles can be worked through while parenting, but others may need real resolution beforehand. Being honest about where you stand is crucial.
One is in a good, long-term relationship that has matured to the point where both partners are ready to settle down, handle the stress of parenting, and trust that they will raise the child properly.
One is married? (A controversial point—this holds more significance for some than for others.)
One has left their childhood home and established themselves as a self-sufficient adult.
One has a good income and career or at least a concrete plan and prospects for financial stability.
One knows how to manage money.
One has reliable transportation, such as a car.

images.alt: Two figures kissing, their faces completely covered by white cloth, in a surreal painting by René Magritte.
images.caption: René Magritte’s 1928 *The Lovers* explores themes of love, isolation, and emotional barriers, with veiled faces symbolizing hidden identities and unattainable intimacy.

paragraphs.content: The most obvious argument for waiting is that if none of the above points are met, you are most likely—but not necessarily—in for quite a disaster when bringing a child into the world. Reaching a state of readiness becomes much more difficult once a child is in the picture.

Without stability, you may find yourself, as a single parent, heartbroken and broke pretty quickly, possibly paying child support from an already meager existence. Or, you may have your hands so full that you have no time or energy left to work on yourself. Sleepless nights and full-time childcare will become your new norm.
All those things you wanted to experience and work on before becoming a parent? Poof! Gone. Life for just yourself is over.

More importantly, your child is the real victim in this situation. They will carry the burden of your mistakes in the form of hardship and may spend their life playing catch-up. Raising a child is a massive responsibility—one that shouldn’t be taken lightly. Children become parents themselves one day, and the damage of your mistakes could echo through multiple generations.

sections.heading: There Is No Such Thing as "Ready"

images.alt: A bizarre surrealist painting showing a group of people inside a giant egg, reading music and playing instruments.
images.caption: Attributed to a follower of Hieronymus Bosch (1561), *Concert in the Egg* is a surreal allegory of ignorance and folly, depicting musicians trapped inside a cracked egg.

paragraphs.content: Or at least, we’ve established that readiness is an abstract concept that exists on a spectrum.

The truth is, you’ll never be fully ready. I personally believe that true maturity is only possible once you become a parent. Looking at myself, I wasn’t doing too badly before I became a parent—I had lived on my own for a few years, earned a modest living, learned to manage my finances, had a driver's license and a car, and had a concrete career plan (which I’m still working on).

But the reality was that I was taking things easy. My actions toward my goals were vague, and progress was slow—if it even happened at all. I was avoiding most of my personal issues and simply enjoying life for myself.
Then, I found out my partner was pregnant. Panic hit me like a right hook to the nose.

Looking back, those nine months leading up to the birth of the love of my life were a period of transformation. I had to say goodbye to my youthful ways and truly become an adult. I became much more honest with myself, took concrete action, and started making real progress.
I believe every man needs that fire under his ass—the one that only becoming a parent can light.

Are things perfect now? Far from it. Every day, I deal with personal issues from my own broken childhood. Things with my partner aren’t always smooth, and I’m still working hard toward my career goals—sometimes feeling like I’m playing catch-up.
Was I ready? I guess so. I believe this will work out. And even if it doesn’t, I will never regret bringing my daughter into this world, because I love her more than anything.

images.alt: A lively 17th-century painting of a family gathering where children imitate the behavior of their elders.
images.caption: Jan Steen’s 1668 *As the Old Sing, So Pipe the Young* humorously depicts how children mirror the actions of adults, reinforcing the idea of generational influence.

paragraphs.content: A guy in some random anime once said, "Opinions are like buttholes—everyone has one." That being said, here’s mine:

Make sure you have the bare minimum in place as early in life as possible, before Mother Nature plays her tricks on you. Have your own place that a woman can turn into a home. Have a career or at least a solid plan. Have reliable transportation. Work on untangling yourself from personal issues as much as possible.
If you come from a troubled background, I’m sorry. Unfortunately, certain problems take generations to fix. But waiting forever isn’t the answer either.

You will never be fully ready. The most important condition, I think, is that you are ready and willing to step up to the occasion once it’s there. If the answer to that is yes, then I believe you’re ready.
Waiting too long can be detrimental. Not only will you miss out on the most beautiful experience life has to offer, but you’ll also never reach the level of maturity that parenthood can bring.
There’s also a biological clock to consider—more pressing for women, but an issue for men as well. You won’t be able to conceive forever.
So don’t wait forever. Get the basics in order, find a good partner, and start a family.
